unit: Unit 6 | Inference for Categorical Data: Proportions
title: Determining a $p$-Value
question_text:
A group of college students in a psychology class wonders if the order of treatments changes the outcome of a study.
To test this, they ask students in a blind taste test which of two colas they prefer, Pepsi or Coke. In this blind taste test, the first $50\text{ randomly chosen subjects}$ are given Pepsi and then Coke, with $34$ preferring Pepsi. The next $50\text{ randomly chosen subjects}$ are given Coke and then Pepsi, with $29$ preferring Pepsi.
Does this give evidence that the order in which colas, or options, are presented makes a difference?
Determine the approximate $p$-value of a test to answer this question.
